canonical_explanation.text: Hydrocarbons are organic compounds composed exclusively of carbon and hydrogen atoms. They are classified into four main categories: alkanes (saturated, single bonds only), alkenes (one or more C=C double bonds), alkynes (one or more C≡C triple bonds), and aromatic hydrocarbons (containing benzene rings or related structures). Alkanes (CₙH₂ₙ₊₂) are prepared by Wurtz reaction, Kolbe electrolysis, decarboxylation, and catalytic hydrogenation of alkenes/alkynes. They undergo substitution reactions (halogenation via free radical mechanism), combustion, and pyrolysis (cracking). Conformations of alkanes involve rotation about C–C single bonds; for ethane, the staggered conformation is most stable and the eclipsed is least stable due to torsional strain. Alkenes (CₙH₂ₙ) are prepared by dehydration of alcohols, dehydrohalogenation of alkyl halides, and dehalogenation of vicinal dihalides. They undergo electrophilic addition reactions following Markovnikov's rule: the electrophile (H⁺) adds to the carbon with more H atoms, and the nucleophile adds to the carbon with fewer H atoms. Anti-Markovnikov addition occurs in the presence of peroxides (Kharash effect). Alkynes (CₙH₂ₙ₋₂) are prepared from calcium carbide, dehydrohalogenation of vicinal dihalides, and by the action of alkyl halides on sodium acetylide. Terminal alkynes are weakly acidic (pKa ~25) because the sp-hybridised carbon has greater s-character (50%), holding electrons closer to the nucleus and stabilising the conjugate base. Aromatic hydrocarbons contain benzene rings characterised by planarity, cyclic conjugation, and (4n+2) pi electrons (Huckel's rule). Benzene undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution (EAS) reactions including halogenation, nitration, sulphonation, Friedel-Crafts alkylation, and Friedel-Crafts acylation. The mechanism involves formation of an electrophile, attack on the pi cloud to form an arenium ion (sigma complex), and loss of a proton to restore aromaticity. Substituents on benzene are classified as activating (ortho-para directors, e.g., –OH, –NH₂, –CH₃) and deactivating (meta directors, e.g., –NO₂, –COOH, –CN), based on their electronic effects. Halogens are deactivating but ortho-para directing due to their +M effect overriding their −I effect for directing purposes.
rules: Alkanes have the general formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ and undergo substitution reactions (not addition).
Wurtz reaction: 2R–X + 2Na → R–R + 2NaX (forms even-carbon alkanes in dry ether).
In ethane conformations: staggered is most stable (lowest energy), eclipsed is least stable (highest torsional strain).
Markovnikov's rule: in HX addition to unsymmetrical alkenes, H adds to the carbon with more H atoms.
Anti-Markovnikov (Kharash) addition occurs with HBr in the presence of peroxides (free radical mechanism).
Terminal alkynes are weakly acidic (pKa ~25) due to 50% s-character in the sp hybrid orbital holding the C–H bonding electrons.
Huckel's rule for aromaticity: a planar, cyclic, fully conjugated system with (4n+2) pi electrons is aromatic.
Benzene undergoes electrophilic aromatic substitution (EAS): halogenation, nitration, sulphonation, Friedel-Crafts reactions.
EAS mechanism: electrophile generation → electrophilic attack forming arenium ion (sigma complex) → proton loss restoring aromaticity.
Ortho-para directors: electron-donating groups (–OH, –NH₂, –OR, –R) activate the ring and direct to ortho/para positions.
Meta directors: electron-withdrawing groups (–NO₂, –CN, –COOH, –CHO) deactivate the ring and direct to the meta position.
Halogens are ortho-para directing but ring deactivating: −I effect deactivates, +M effect directs to ortho/para.

questions.question_text: The general formula of alkanes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with only single bonds between carbon atoms. Their general formula is CₙH₂ₙ₊₂, where n is the number of carbon atoms (e.g., methane CH₄, ethane C₂H₆, propane C₃H₈).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CₙH₂ₙ is the general formula for alkenes (or cycloalkanes). CₙH₂ₙ₋₂ is for alkynes. CₙHₙ does not correspond to any standard hydrocarbon class. Alkanes, being fully saturated, have the maximum H:C ratio given by CₙH₂ₙ₊₂.

questions.question_text: In the Wurtz reaction, two molecules of an alkyl halide react with sodium in dry ether to form:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Wurtz reaction, 2R–X + 2Na → R–R + 2NaX. Two alkyl halide molecules couple in the presence of sodium metal in dry ether to form a symmetric alkane with double the number of carbon atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Wurtz reaction does not produce alkenes, alcohols, or alkoxides. It specifically couples two alkyl groups via C–C bond formation, yielding a higher alkane and sodium halide.

questions.question_text: The most stable conformation of ethane is:
questions.explanation_correct: The staggered conformation of ethane is the most stable because the hydrogen atoms on adjacent carbons are maximally separated (dihedral angle of 60°), minimising torsional strain. The eclipsed conformation is the least stable, about 12.5 kJ/mol higher in energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eclipsed conformation has maximum torsional strain due to close proximity of H atoms on adjacent carbons. Gauche is a term used for butane conformations. The staggered form of ethane is the global energy minimum.

questions.question_text: The halogenation of alkanes proceeds by a mechanism that is:
questions.explanation_correct: Halogenation of alkanes (e.g., CH₄ + Cl₂ → CH₃Cl + HCl) proceeds by a free radical chain mechanism involving three steps: initiation (Cl₂ → 2Cl· by UV light or heat), propagation (Cl· + CH₄ → CH₃· + HCl; CH₃· + Cl₂ → CH₃Cl + Cl·), and termination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrophilic addition is typical of alkenes. Nucleophilic substitution occurs with alkyl halides. Electrophilic substitution is characteristic of benzene. Alkane halogenation specifically follows a free radical chain mechanism initiated by homolytic cleavage.

questions.question_text: The most stable conformation of n-butane is:
questions.explanation_correct: The anti conformation of n-butane, where the two methyl groups are 180° apart (anti-periplanar), is the most stable. It has minimum steric strain because the bulky methyl groups are maximally separated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fully eclipsed conformation (methyl groups 0° apart) has the highest energy due to maximum steric and torsional strain. The gauche conformation (60° dihedral) has slight steric strain. The anti conformation is the global minimum.

questions.question_text: In the chlorination of propane, the ratio of 1-chloropropane to 2-chloropropane is approximately 45:55. This indicates that:

options.text: Primary hydrogens are more reactive than secondary hydrogens
Secondary hydrogens are more reactive than primary hydrogens
Both types of hydrogens are equally reactive
Only secondary hydrogens react with chlorine

questions.explanation_correct: Propane has 6 primary H atoms and 2 secondary H atoms. If all were equally reactive, the ratio would be 6:2 = 75:25. Since the actual ratio is ~45:55, secondary hydrogens are about 3.8 times more reactive than primary hydrogens toward chlorine radicals. The secondary C–H bond is weaker and the secondary radical is more stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If primary hydrogens were more reactive, 1-chloropropane would predominate even more than the statistical ratio (75:25). Equal reactivity would give a 75:25 ratio. The higher-than-expected proportion of 2-chloropropane proves secondary H atoms are more reactive.

questions.question_text: Kolbe's electrolytic method involves electrolysis of an aqueous solution of sodium or potassium salt of a carboxylic acid to produce:

options.text: A higher alkane at the anode
A lower alkane at the cathode

questions.explanation_correct: In Kolbe's electrolysis, the carboxylate ions (RCOO⁻) migrate to the anode, where they are oxidised and decarboxylated to form alkyl radicals that couple to give a higher alkane: 2RCOO⁻ → R–R + 2CO₂ + 2e⁻. For example, sodium acetate gives ethane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The product at the anode is an alkane formed by radical coupling, not an alcohol or aldehyde. The alkane is formed at the anode (not cathode), where oxidation and decarboxylation occur.

questions.question_text: Pyrolysis (cracking) of alkanes involves:

options.text: Heating alkanes in the presence of water to form alcohols
Breaking down higher alkanes into smaller molecules by heating in the absence of air
Reaction of alkanes with halogens in ultraviolet light

questions.explanation_correct: Pyrolysis (thermal cracking) is the decomposition of higher alkanes into a mixture of lower alkanes, alkenes, and hydrogen by heating at high temperatures (700-1200 K) in the absence of air. This is an important industrial process in petroleum refining.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating with water is hydrolysis, not pyrolysis. KMnO₄ oxidation does not occur readily with alkanes. Reaction with halogens is halogenation. Pyrolysis specifically involves thermal decomposition in the absence of oxygen.

questions.question_text: Decarboxylation of sodium propanoate (CH₃CH₂COONa) with soda lime produces:
questions.explanation_correct: Decarboxylation with soda lime (NaOH + CaO) removes the carboxyl group as Na₂CO₃ and produces an alkane with one fewer carbon: CH₃CH₂COONa + NaOH → CH₃CH₃ (ethane) + Na₂CO₃. The product has n-1 carbons compared to the acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propane would have 3 carbons, but decarboxylation removes one carbon (as CO₂/Na₂CO₃). Methane would result from sodium acetate. Butane has too many carbons. Sodium propanoate (3C acid) gives ethane (2C alkane).

questions.question_text: Alkanes are also known as:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkanes are called paraffins (from Latin 'parum affinis' meaning 'little affinity') because they are relatively unreactive. They undergo very few reactions under normal conditions due to the strong, non-polar C–C and C–H bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Olefins is the common name for alkenes. Acetylenes refers to alkynes. Aromatics are benzene and its derivatives. Paraffins specifically refers to alkanes due to their low reactivity.

questions.question_text: The general formula of alkenes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkenes contain one C=C double bond and have the general formula CₙH₂ₙ (where n ≥ 2). For example, ethene is C₂H₄, propene is C₃H₆, and butene is C₄H₈.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ is for alkanes (saturated). CₙH₂ₙ₋₂ is for alkynes (triple bond). CₙH₂ₙ₋₆ applies to benzene derivatives. Alkenes with one double bond follow CₙH₂ₙ.

questions.question_text: Alkenes are commonly prepared in the laboratory by:

options.text: Hydrogenation of alkynes using Pd/C catalyst

questions.explanation_correct: Acid-catalysed dehydration of alcohols is a common laboratory method for preparing alkenes. For example, ethanol heated with concentrated H₂SO₄ at 170°C gives ethene. The ease of dehydration follows: tertiary > secondary > primary alcohols (Saytzeff's rule).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydrogenation of alkynes with Pd/C gives alkanes (over-reduction), not alkenes (Lindlar's catalyst is needed for partial reduction to alkenes). Wurtz reaction and Kolbe's electrolysis produce alkanes.

questions.question_text: Markovnikov's rule states that in the addition of HX to an unsymmetrical alkene:

options.text: The halide ion adds to the carbon with more hydrogen atoms
The hydrogen adds to the carbon with fewer hydrogen atoms
The hydrogen adds to the carbon with more hydrogen atoms
The halide adds equally to both carbons

questions.explanation_correct: Markovnikov's rule: when HX adds to an unsymmetrical alkene, the hydrogen atom adds to the carbon that already has more hydrogen atoms (the less substituted carbon), and the halide adds to the more substituted carbon. This produces the more stable carbocation intermediate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If hydrogen added to the carbon with fewer H atoms, that would be anti-Markovnikov addition. Markovnikov's rule specifically places H on the carbon bearing more hydrogens, so the more stable (more substituted) carbocation intermediate is formed.

questions.question_text: The addition of HBr to propene in the presence of benzoyl peroxide gives predominantly:
questions.explanation_correct: In the presence of peroxides (Kharash effect), HBr adds to propene via a free radical mechanism, giving anti-Markovnikov product (1-bromopropane). The Br radical adds to the less substituted carbon, forming the more stable secondary radical intermediate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Without peroxide, HBr follows Markovnikov's rule giving 2-bromopropane. But with peroxide, the mechanism switches to free radical, and the anti-Markovnikov product (1-bromopropane) predominates. This peroxide effect is observed only with HBr, not with HCl or HI.

questions.question_text: Ozonolysis of but-2-ene followed by treatment with Zn/H₂O produces:

options.text: One molecule of acetaldehyde and one of formaldehyde
One molecule of acetone and one of formaldehyde

questions.explanation_correct: But-2-ene (CH₃CH=CHCH₃) on ozonolysis with Zn/H₂O (reductive workup) cleaves the double bond to give two molecules of acetaldehyde (CH₃CHO). Each fragment has one carbon from the original double bond plus its substituents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formaldehyde (HCHO) would result from a terminal =CH₂ group, which but-2-ene does not have. Acetone would require a trisubstituted carbon at the double bond. Since both carbons of the C=C in but-2-ene carry one H and one CH₃, two molecules of CH₃CHO are produced.

questions.question_text: When ethene is treated with cold dilute alkaline KMnO₄ (Baeyer's reagent), the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cold dilute alkaline KMnO₄ (Baeyer's reagent) performs syn-hydroxylation of alkenes. Ethene gives ethylene glycol (ethane-1,2-diol, HOCH₂CH₂OH). The decolourisation of KMnO₄ (purple to colourless/brown) is used as a test for unsaturation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethanol would require reduction (addition of H₂). Acetaldehyde would result from Wacker oxidation. Oxalic acid would require hot, concentrated KMnO₄. Cold dilute alkaline KMnO₄ specifically adds two OH groups across the double bond, forming a vicinal diol.

questions.question_text: Saytzeff's (Zaitsev's) rule predicts that in the dehydration of butan-2-ol, the major product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Saytzeff's rule states that in elimination reactions, the more substituted (more stable) alkene is the major product. Dehydration of butan-2-ol can give but-1-ene or but-2-ene. But-2-ene is more substituted (disubstituted) and is the major product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: But-1-ene is the less substituted (monosubstituted) alkene and is the minor product. 2-Methylpropene has a different carbon skeleton. Butane would require reduction, not elimination. Saytzeff's rule predicts but-2-ene as the major product.

questions.question_text: The peroxide effect (Kharash effect) is observed with:
questions.explanation_correct: The peroxide effect (anti-Markovnikov addition) is observed only with HBr. HCl does not show this effect because the Cl radical is not reactive enough to initiate the chain. HI does not show it because the I radical is too reactive and the chain terminates prematurely. Only HBr has the right balance of bond energy for sustained radical chain propagation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCl has too strong an H–Cl bond for the radical chain to propagate efficiently. HI has too weak an H–I bond, causing premature termination. The Kharash effect is unique to HBr because the propagation steps are both exothermic.

questions.question_text: Alkenes can be distinguished from alkanes using:
questions.explanation_correct: Bromine water (Br₂/H₂O) is decolourised by alkenes due to electrophilic addition of bromine across the C=C double bond. Alkanes do not react with bromine water under normal conditions. This serves as a simple test to distinguish alkenes from alkanes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium metal reacts with alcohols and terminal alkynes, not specifically with alkenes. Concentrated H₂SO₄ can react with both (under different conditions). Silver nitrate is used for halide detection. Bromine water decolourisation is the classic test for unsaturation.

questions.question_text: Catalytic hydrogenation of propene with H₂ in the presence of Ni at 250°C gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Catalytic hydrogenation adds H₂ across the C=C double bond of propene (CH₃CH=CH₂) to give propane (CH₃CH₂CH₃). The catalyst (Ni, Pt, or Pd) facilitates the addition at moderate temperatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propyne has a triple bond and would require dehydrogenation, not hydrogenation. Cyclopropane has a ring structure. Propan-1-ol would require hydration. Hydrogenation simply saturates the double bond to give the corresponding alkane.

questions.question_text: The general formula of alkynes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Alkynes contain one C≡C triple bond and have the general formula CₙH₂ₙ₋₂ (where n ≥ 2). For example, ethyne (acetylene) is C₂H₂, propyne is C₃H₄.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ is for alkanes, CₙH₂ₙ is for alkenes, and CₙH₂ₙ₋₄ does not correspond to simple alkynes. The triple bond reduces the hydrogen count by 4 compared to the alkane, giving CₙH₂ₙ₋₂.

questions.question_text: Acetylene (ethyne) is industrially prepared from:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetylene is industrially prepared by the action of water on calcium carbide: CaC₂ + 2H₂O → C₂H₂ + Ca(OH)₂. This is a simple and widely used method for generating acetylene gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium acetate with soda lime gives methane (decarboxylation). Ethanol with H₂SO₄ gives ethene (dehydration). Ethylene with chlorine gives 1,2-dichloroethane. The calcium carbide method is the standard industrial preparation of acetylene.

questions.question_text: Terminal alkynes are weakly acidic because:

options.text: The C≡C bond is very strong
The sp carbon has 50% s-character, holding electrons closer to the nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: In terminal alkynes (R–C≡C–H), the carbon of the C–H bond is sp hybridised with 50% s-character. The higher s-character means the bonding electrons are held closer to the carbon nucleus, making it easier to release the proton. The conjugate base (acetylide anion) is stabilised by the high s-character.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bond strength of C≡C does not directly explain acidity of the C–H bond. Having fewer hydrogens is not related to acid strength. The electron-richness of the triple bond is not the reason. The key factor is the 50% s-character of the sp orbital forming the C–H bond.

questions.question_text: When propyne is treated with dilute H₂SO₄ in the presence of HgSO₄, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydration of propyne (an internal position following Markovnikov's rule) with dilute H₂SO₄/HgSO₄ first gives an enol, which tautomerises to acetone (propanone, CH₃COCH₃). Only ethyne gives an aldehyde (acetaldehyde) on hydration; higher alkynes give ketones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanal would be an anti-Markovnikov product. Propan-1-ol and propanoic acid are not products of simple hydration of alkynes. Markovnikov addition of water to propyne gives the enol of acetone, which tautomerises to propanone.

questions.question_text: Terminal alkynes react with sodium metal to form:

options.text: Sodium acetylide with liberation of H₂

questions.explanation_correct: Terminal alkynes (R–C≡C–H) react with sodium metal to form sodium acetylide (R–C≡C⁻Na⁺) with evolution of hydrogen gas: R–C≡C–H + Na → R–C≡C⁻Na⁺ + ½H₂. This reaction demonstrates the acidic nature of terminal alkynes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium alkoxide is formed from alcohols and Na. Alkanes do not react with Na. Sodium carboxylates are formed from carboxylic acids. Terminal alkynes specifically give sodium acetylides due to their acidic C≡C–H hydrogen.

questions.question_text: The acidity of hydrocarbons follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: Acidity order: Alkyne (sp, 50% s) > Alkene (sp², 33% s) > Alkane (sp³, 25% s). Greater s-character in the hybrid orbital means electrons are held closer to the nucleus, the C–H bond is more polar, and the conjugate base is more stable. pKa values: alkyne ~25, alkene ~44, alkane ~50.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The s-character of the carbon orbital in the C–H bond determines acidity: sp (50% s) > sp² (33% s) > sp³ (25% s). Higher s-character stabilises the negative charge on the conjugate base. Therefore, alkynes are the most acidic.

questions.question_text: Lindlar's catalyst (Pd/BaSO₄ poisoned with quinoline) is used to:
questions.explanation_correct: Lindlar's catalyst is a partially deactivated (poisoned) palladium catalyst that selectively reduces alkynes to cis-alkenes (syn addition of H₂). The poisoning prevents further reduction to the alkane. The product is the cis (Z) isomer because both H atoms add from the same face.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkenes to alkanes requires a normal hydrogenation catalyst (Pd/C, Pt, or Ni). Trans-alkenes from alkynes require Birch reduction (Na in liquid NH₃). Lindlar's catalyst specifically gives cis-alkenes by partial hydrogenation of alkynes.

questions.question_text: An organic compound gives a white precipitate with ammoniacal silver nitrate solution. The compound is most likely:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethyne (HC≡CH) is a terminal alkyne that gives a white precipitate of silver acetylide (Ag₂C₂) with ammoniacal AgNO₃ (Tollens' reagent): C₂H₂ + 2[Ag(NH₃)₂]⁺ → Ag₂C₂↓ + 2NH₄⁺ + 2NH₃. This is a characteristic test for terminal alkynes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethane and ethene do not react with ammoniacal silver nitrate. Benzene is aromatic and does not have an acidic hydrogen. Only terminal alkynes (like ethyne) form insoluble metal acetylides — silver acetylide is a white precipitate.

questions.question_text: Birch reduction of an alkyne (using Na/liquid NH₃) gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Birch reduction (Na or Li in liquid NH₃) of an alkyne gives a trans-alkene (anti addition). The dissolving metal reduction proceeds through a vinyl radical/anion intermediate, and the geometry favours the trans (E) product due to the stepwise mechanism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cis-alkene is formed by catalytic hydrogenation with Lindlar's catalyst (syn addition). An alkane would result from complete reduction. Birch reduction specifically produces the trans-alkene through an anti addition pathway.

questions.question_text: Propyne can be distinguished from propene by reaction with:
questions.explanation_correct: Ammoniacal cuprous chloride (Cu₂Cl₂/NH₄OH) gives a red precipitate of copper acetylide (Cu₂C₂ or RCu) with terminal alkynes like propyne, but does not react with alkenes. Bromine water would decolourise with both propyne and propene, so it cannot distinguish between them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bromine water reacts with both alkenes and alkynes (decolourisation). H₂SO₄ and H₂/Ni also react with both. Ammoniacal cuprous chloride is specific for terminal alkynes, giving a characteristic red precipitate that identifies propyne.

questions.question_text: According to Huckel's rule, a molecule is aromatic if it has _____ pi electrons in a planar, cyclic, fully conjugated system.
questions.explanation_correct: Huckel's rule states that a planar, cyclic, fully conjugated molecule with (4n + 2) pi electrons (where n = 0, 1, 2, 3, ...) is aromatic. For benzene, n = 1, giving 4(1) + 2 = 6 pi electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4n pi electrons correspond to anti-aromatic systems (e.g., cyclobutadiene with 4 electrons). The formula 4n + 2 specifically predicts aromaticity, not 4n, 4n + 1, or 2n + 1.

questions.question_text: Benzene preferentially undergoes _____ reactions rather than addition reactions.
questions.explanation_correct: Benzene undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions (halogenation, nitration, sulphonation, Friedel-Crafts) rather than addition reactions. This preserves the aromatic sextet (6 pi electrons) and the associated resonance stabilisation energy (~150 kJ/mol).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Addition reactions would disrupt the aromatic system. Elimination and nucleophilic addition are not typical of benzene. Electrophilic substitution maintains aromaticity by replacing one H atom with an electrophile without breaking the delocalised pi system.

questions.question_text: The number of pi electrons in benzene is:
questions.explanation_correct: Benzene (C₆H₆) has three C=C double bonds (in the Kekule structure), contributing 6 pi electrons. These 6 electrons are delocalised over all six carbon atoms in a continuous ring. This satisfies Huckel's rule (4n + 2 = 6, where n = 1).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzene has exactly 6 pi electrons from three pairs of p-orbital overlap. Two electrons would be far too few for a six-membered ring. 4 and 8 would violate Huckel's rule for aromaticity.

questions.question_text: In the nitration of benzene, the electrophile is:
questions.explanation_correct: The electrophile in nitration is the nitronium ion (NO₂⁺), generated from the reaction of concentrated HNO₃ with concentrated H₂SO₄: HNO₃ + H₂SO₄ → NO₂⁺ + HSO₄⁻ + H₂O. The NO₂⁺ attacks the pi-electron cloud of benzene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NO₂⁻ is a nucleophile, not an electrophile. The intact HNO₃ molecule is not electrophilic enough to attack benzene. NO is a neutral radical. The active electrophile is specifically the nitronium ion (NO₂⁺).

questions.question_text: Friedel-Crafts alkylation of benzene with CH₃Cl in the presence of anhydrous AlCl₃ gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Friedel-Crafts alkylation introduces an alkyl group onto the benzene ring. CH₃Cl + AlCl₃ generates the electrophile (CH₃⁺ or CH₃-Cl-AlCl₃ complex), which attacks benzene to form toluene (methylbenzene) and HCl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorobenzene is formed by Friedel-Crafts halogenation (Cl₂/AlCl₃). Benzaldehyde would require formylation. Phenol requires hydroxylation. Friedel-Crafts alkylation with CH₃Cl specifically gives toluene (C₆H₅CH₃).

questions.question_text: The intermediate formed during electrophilic aromatic substitution (EAS) is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In EAS, the electrophile attacks the pi cloud of benzene to form a positively charged cyclohexadienyl cation known as the arenium ion (or sigma complex or Wheland intermediate). This intermediate then loses a proton to restore aromaticity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A carbanion is a negatively charged carbon. Benzyne is an intermediate in nucleophilic aromatic substitution. A Meisenheimer complex is formed in SNAr reactions. The EAS intermediate is specifically the arenium ion (sigma complex).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is anti-aromatic?
questions.explanation_correct: Cyclobutadiene has 4 pi electrons (4n, where n = 1), is planar, cyclic, and fully conjugated. It satisfies the criteria for anti-aromaticity: a planar, cyclic, conjugated system with 4n pi electrons. Anti-aromatic compounds are highly unstable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzene (6 pi electrons) is aromatic. Cyclooctatetraene is not planar (tub-shaped) so it is non-aromatic, not anti-aromatic. Cyclobutadienyl dianion has 6 pi electrons and is aromatic. Cyclobutadiene with 4 pi electrons is the classic anti-aromatic compound.

questions.question_text: Sulphonation of benzene with fuming H₂SO₄ produces:
questions.explanation_correct: Sulphonation is an electrophilic aromatic substitution where SO₃ (the electrophile, present in fuming H₂SO₄) attacks benzene to form benzenesulphonic acid (C₆H₅SO₃H). This reaction is reversible — heating with dilute H₂SO₄ removes the sulphonic acid group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenol is formed by fusion of benzenesulphonate with NaOH. Benzoic acid requires oxidation of a side chain. Benzaldehyde requires specific oxidation conditions. Sulphonation directly gives benzenesulphonic acid.

questions.question_text: Friedel-Crafts reaction does NOT occur with:
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrobenzene does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reactions because the –NO₂ group is a strong deactivating group that makes the ring too electron-poor to react with the electrophile. Friedel-Crafts reactions fail with rings bearing strong deactivating groups (–NO₂, –CN, –CHO, etc.).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Toluene has an activating methyl group and readily undergoes Friedel-Crafts reactions. Anisole (–OCH₃) is activated. Chlorobenzene, though deactivated, can still undergo Friedel-Crafts reactions under vigorous conditions. Only nitrobenzene is too deactivated.

questions.question_text: All C–C bond lengths in benzene are equal at:
questions.explanation_correct: All six C–C bonds in benzene are identical and have a bond length of 1.39 Å, which is intermediate between a typical C–C single bond (1.54 Å) and a C=C double bond (1.34 Å). This reflects the delocalised nature of the pi electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.34 Å is for a localised C=C double bond. 1.54 Å is for a C–C single bond. 1.20 Å is for a C≡C triple bond. Benzene's 1.39 Å bond length confirms that its bonds are neither purely single nor purely double — they are resonance-averaged.

questions.question_text: In electrophilic aromatic substitution, the –OH group directs incoming electrophiles to:
questions.explanation_correct: The –OH group is an activating, ortho-para directing group due to its +M (resonance) effect. The lone pair on oxygen is donated into the ring, increasing electron density at ortho and para positions, making these positions more reactive toward electrophiles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The –OH group does not direct exclusively to ortho or meta. Meta direction would require a deactivating group. The electron donation by –OH through resonance specifically enhances ortho and para positions, not all positions equally.

questions.question_text: The –NO₂ group on benzene is:
questions.explanation_correct: The –NO₂ group is strongly electron-withdrawing by both −I and −M effects. It deactivates the benzene ring (decreasing the rate of EAS) and directs incoming electrophiles to the meta position, where the destabilising effect on the arenium ion intermediate is minimised.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NO₂ withdraws electron density from the ring, making it less reactive (deactivating). The electron withdrawal destabilises ortho/para intermediates more than meta intermediates, so the meta product predominates. –NO₂ is deactivating and meta directing.

questions.question_text: Halogens (–Cl, –Br) attached to benzene are unusual because they are:
questions.explanation_correct: Halogens are deactivating (due to strong −I effect reducing overall electron density) but ortho-para directing (due to +M effect donating lone pair electrons into the ring, which stabilises ortho/para arenium ion intermediates more than meta). The directing effect (+M) and the activating/deactivating effect (−I) operate by different mechanisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Halogens are not activating — their −I effect reduces the rate of EAS. They are not meta directing — their +M effect stabilises ortho/para intermediates. The unique combination of deactivating (−I) and ortho-para directing (+M) makes halogens exceptional.

questions.question_text: Nitration of toluene gives predominantly:

options.text: A mixture of o-nitrotoluene and p-nitrotoluene

questions.explanation_correct: The –CH₃ group in toluene is an activating, ortho-para directing group (+I and hyperconjugation effects). Nitration gives a mixture of o-nitrotoluene (~58%) and p-nitrotoluene (~38%), with very little meta product (~4%). Under mild conditions, monosubstitution predominates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: m-Nitrotoluene would be expected only if –CH₃ were meta directing (it is not). Only p-nitrotoluene would underestimate the ortho product. 2,4,6-Trinitrotoluene (TNT) forms only under forcing conditions with excess nitrating mixture. The major products are ortho and para isomers.

questions.question_text: Chlorination of nitrobenzene gives predominantly:

options.text: An equal mixture of all three isomers

questions.explanation_correct: The –NO₂ group is a deactivating, meta-directing substituent. In the chlorination of nitrobenzene, the electrophile (Cl⁺) attacks predominantly at the meta position, giving m-chloronitrobenzene as the major product.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NO₂ withdraws electron density from ortho and para positions more than from the meta position, destabilising ortho/para arenium ion intermediates. The meta intermediate is relatively more stable, so m-chloronitrobenzene predominates.

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups is a meta director in electrophilic aromatic substitution?
questions.explanation_correct: The –CHO (aldehyde) group is an electron-withdrawing group (−M and −I effects) that deactivates the benzene ring and directs incoming electrophiles to the meta position. Other meta directors include –COOH, –NO₂, –CN, –COCH₃, and –SO₃H.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –OCH₃ and –NH₂ are activating ortho-para directors (strong +M effect). –CH₃ is an activating ortho-para director (+I and hyperconjugation). Only –CHO, with its electron-withdrawing carbonyl, directs to the meta position.

questions.question_text: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) such as benzopyrene are significant because they are:

options.text: Potent carcinogens found in tobacco smoke and charred food

questions.explanation_correct: Benzopyrene and other polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are potent carcinogens. They are found in tobacco smoke, automobile exhaust, charred/grilled food, and coal tar. They cause cancer by reacting with DNA after metabolic activation in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PAHs are not food additives or vitamins — they are harmful pollutants. They are not easily biodegradable. Benzopyrene is one of the most well-studied chemical carcinogens and poses significant health risks.

questions.question_text: In a disubstituted benzene, if one group is ortho-para directing and the other is meta directing, the new electrophile enters the ring at a position directed by:

options.text: Neither group — equal mixture at all positions
Only the para position relative to both groups

questions.explanation_correct: When two groups with conflicting directive effects are present, the ortho-para directing (activating) group generally controls the orientation of the incoming electrophile. The activating group makes certain positions more electron-rich, facilitating electrophilic attack there.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The meta director is also a deactivating group, so it has less influence on directing compared to the activating ortho-para director. The incoming electrophile enters at positions that are ortho/para to the activating group (and also taking steric effects into account).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct order of reactivity toward electrophilic aromatic substitution?
questions.explanation_correct: Reactivity toward EAS depends on electron density in the ring. Activating groups (electron-donating) increase reactivity: Phenol (–OH, strong +M) > Toluene (–CH₃, +I/hyperconjugation) > Benzene (no substituent) > Nitrobenzene (–NO₂, strong −M/−I, deactivating).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrobenzene is the least reactive due to the strong deactivating –NO₂ group. Benzene is the reference. Toluene is more reactive than benzene. Phenol is the most reactive due to the strong electron-donating +M effect of –OH.

questions.question_text: Carbon tetrachloride (CCl₄) was previously used as a fire extinguisher and dry cleaning solvent. It has been largely phased out because it is:

options.text: Toxic to the liver and kidneys and an ozone-depleting substance

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon tetrachloride is highly toxic, causing liver and kidney damage. It is also an ozone-depleting substance. Due to these health and environmental hazards, its use has been largely discontinued and replaced by safer alternatives.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CCl₄ is not expensive to produce or highly flammable (in fact, its non-flammability made it useful as a fire extinguisher). It is quite stable chemically. The primary reasons for discontinuation are its toxicity and contribution to ozone depletion.

questions.question_text: How does the free radical halogenation of alkanes with Cl₂ differ from that with Br₂ in terms of selectivity?

options.text: Chlorination is more selective than bromination toward tertiary C–H bonds
Bromination is more selective than chlorination toward tertiary C–H bonds
Both show identical selectivity toward primary, secondary, and tertiary C–H bonds
Chlorination is selective but bromination is completely non-selective

questions.explanation_correct: Bromination is far more selective than chlorination. The Br· radical is less reactive and more selective — it preferentially abstracts tertiary H atoms (selectivity ratio ~1600:1 for 3°:1°). The Cl· radical is more reactive and less selective (~4:1 for 3°:1°). This follows the reactivity-selectivity principle: the more endothermic the H-abstraction step, the more the transition state resembles the product radical, and the greater the selectivity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorination is not more selective — Cl· is a highly reactive, less discriminating radical. They do not show identical selectivity; bromination is dramatically more selective. Bromination is highly selective (not non-selective), preferring tertiary > secondary > primary H atoms by large factors.

questions.question_text: How does the product of addition of HBr to propene differ in the absence versus the presence of benzoyl peroxide?

options.text: Both conditions give 2-bromopropane as the major product

questions.explanation_correct: Without peroxide, HBr adds to propene via an ionic (electrophilic addition) mechanism following Markovnikov's rule: H adds to the terminal carbon (more H atoms) and Br to the internal carbon, giving 2-bromopropane. With peroxide (Kharash effect), the mechanism switches to free radical addition: Br· adds to the terminal carbon (forming the more stable secondary radical), and H adds to the internal carbon, giving 1-bromopropane (anti-Markovnikov product).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assignments in option A are reversed. Both conditions do not give the same product — the peroxide fundamentally changes the mechanism from ionic to radical. Propan-2-ol is not a product of HBr addition. The key distinction is Markovnikov (ionic) vs anti-Markovnikov (radical) pathways.

questions.question_text: How does the product of partial hydrogenation of but-2-yne differ when Lindlar's catalyst is used versus Na in liquid NH₃ (Birch reduction)?

options.text: Lindlar's catalyst gives trans-but-2-ene; Birch reduction gives cis-but-2-ene
Lindlar's catalyst gives cis-but-2-ene; Birch reduction gives trans-but-2-ene
Both give cis-but-2-ene as the only product
Lindlar's catalyst gives butane; Birch reduction gives trans-but-2-ene

questions.explanation_correct: Lindlar's catalyst (Pd/BaSO₄ poisoned with quinoline) performs syn-addition of H₂ to the alkyne, delivering both hydrogen atoms from the same face, yielding the cis (Z) alkene. Birch reduction (Na/liquid NH₃) proceeds via a radical anion mechanism with anti-addition, producing the trans (E) alkene. These two methods are complementary for stereoselective synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the stereochemistry. Both methods do not give the same product — they give opposite geometric isomers. Lindlar's catalyst is a partial hydrogenation catalyst that stops at the alkene stage (not butane). The stereochemical outcome depends on the mechanism: syn (catalytic) vs anti (dissolving metal).

questions.question_text: How does benzene differ from cyclohexatriene (hypothetical Kekule structure with three isolated double bonds) in terms of hydrogenation enthalpy?

options.text: Benzene has a higher hydrogenation enthalpy than expected, showing it is less stable
Benzene has a lower hydrogenation enthalpy than expected by about 150 kJ/mol, showing extra stabilisation due to resonance
Both have the same hydrogenation enthalpy since both have three double bonds
Benzene has zero hydrogenation enthalpy because it does not react with H₂

questions.explanation_correct: The expected hydrogenation enthalpy of cyclohexatriene (3 × 119.5 kJ/mol = 358.5 kJ/mol based on cyclohexene) would be ~358 kJ/mol. The actual hydrogenation enthalpy of benzene is only ~208 kJ/mol, which is about 150 kJ/mol lower. This difference is the resonance stabilisation energy (delocalisation energy) of benzene, demonstrating that the delocalised pi system is significantly more stable than three isolated double bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzene does not have higher enthalpy than expected — it has lower, meaning it is more stable. The hydrogenation enthalpies are not equal because benzene is resonance-stabilised. Benzene can be hydrogenated (to cyclohexane) under forcing conditions (high pressure, high temperature, Ni catalyst), but it requires more vigorous conditions than simple alkenes.

questions.question_text: How does the –NH₂ group differ from the –NO₂ group in their effect on the rate and orientation of electrophilic aromatic substitution on benzene?

options.text: –NH₂ activates the ring and directs ortho/para; –NO₂ deactivates the ring and directs meta
Both activate the ring but –NH₂ directs ortho/para while –NO₂ directs meta
–NH₂ deactivates the ring and directs meta; –NO₂ activates and directs ortho/para
Both deactivate the ring but with opposite directing effects

questions.explanation_correct: The –NH₂ group has a strong +M (resonance electron-donating) effect: its lone pair is donated into the ring, increasing electron density especially at ortho and para positions. This activates the ring and directs electrophiles to ortho/para. The –NO₂ group has strong −M and −I effects: it withdraws electron density from the ring, deactivating it. The withdrawal destabilises ortho/para arenium ions more than meta, so the electrophile is directed to the meta position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NO₂ does not activate the ring — it is a strong deactivator. –NH₂ does not deactivate or direct meta — it is a strong activator and ortho-para director. They differ fundamentally in both rate effect (activation vs deactivation) and directing effect (o,p vs m).

questions.question_text: A cyclic, planar, fully conjugated hydrocarbon has 10 pi electrons. Based on these properties, this compound should be classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A planar, cyclic, fully conjugated system with 10 pi electrons satisfies Huckel's rule: 4n + 2 = 10, giving n = 2. Since it meets all three criteria — planarity, cyclic conjugation, and (4n + 2) pi electrons — it is aromatic. An example is the cyclodecapentaenyl system (or naphthalene with 10 pi electrons).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anti-aromatic systems have 4n pi electrons (e.g., 4, 8, 12). Non-aromatic systems either lack planarity or full conjugation. 10 pi electrons fit 4n + 2 with n = 2, clearly satisfying Huckel's rule for aromaticity.

questions.question_text: A substituent on benzene increases the rate of electrophilic aromatic substitution and gives predominantly ortho and para products. The substituent can be classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A substituent that increases the rate of EAS is activating (it donates electron density into the ring). Giving predominantly ortho and para products means it directs to those positions. This combination — activating and ortho-para directing — is characteristic of electron-donating groups such as –OH, –NH₂, –OCH₃, –CH₃, and –R (alkyl groups). These groups donate electrons by +M or +I effects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deactivating groups decrease the rate. Meta directors send the electrophile to the meta position. A group that both increases rate and gives o,p products is classified as activating and ortho-para directing. Activating meta directors do not exist among common substituents.

questions.question_text: An organic compound has the molecular formula C₅H₁₂, is saturated, shows no reaction with bromine water or Baeyer's reagent, and undergoes free radical substitution with Cl₂ in UV light. This compound belongs to the class of:
questions.explanation_correct: The molecular formula C₅H₁₂ fits CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ (n = 5), indicating a fully saturated hydrocarbon. No reaction with bromine water or Baeyer's reagent (cold dilute KMnO₄) confirms the absence of double or triple bonds. Undergoing free radical substitution with Cl₂/UV is characteristic of alkanes. This compound is pentane (or an isomer of pentane).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkenes (CₙH₂ₙ) and alkynes (CₙH₂ₙ₋₂) would decolourise bromine water and Baeyer's reagent. Aromatic hydrocarbons have a degree of unsaturation and a different molecular formula pattern. The saturated formula, unreactivity toward unsaturation tests, and free radical substitution all point to alkanes.

questions.question_text: An organic compound of formula C₃H₄ gives a red precipitate with ammoniacal Cu₂Cl₂ and a white precipitate with ammoniacal AgNO₃. This compound is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The molecular formula C₃H₄ fits CₙH₂ₙ₋₂ (n = 3), indicating an alkyne. Giving a red precipitate with ammoniacal cuprous chloride and a white precipitate with ammoniacal silver nitrate are characteristic tests for terminal alkynes (R–C≡C–H). The compound is propyne (CH₃–C≡C–H), which has an acidic terminal hydrogen that forms metal acetylides.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cyclopropene would not give metal acetylide precipitates. Internal alkynes (like but-2-yne) lack the terminal C–H and do not react with these reagents. Aromatic hydrocarbons do not fit C₃H₄. Only terminal alkynes give characteristic precipitates with ammoniacal Cu₂Cl₂ (red) and AgNO₃ (white).

questions.question_text: Riya is performing an experiment in her school laboratory. She heats ethanol with excess concentrated H₂SO₄ at 170°C and collects the gas produced over water. She then passes the gas through bromine water and observes that the reddish-brown colour disappears. The gas Riya collected is:

options.text: Ethane, because H₂SO₄ reduces ethanol to an alkane
Ethene, because acid-catalysed dehydration of ethanol at 170°C produces an alkene
Diethyl ether, because H₂SO₄ dehydrates ethanol at all temperatures to give ether
Acetylene, because concentrated H₂SO₄ removes two molecules of water from ethanol

questions.explanation_correct: Heating ethanol with excess concentrated H₂SO₄ at 170°C causes intramolecular dehydration (elimination), producing ethene (CH₂=CH₂) and water. Ethene decolourises bromine water due to electrophilic addition of Br₂ across the C=C double bond, forming 1,2-dibromoethane. At 140°C, intermolecular dehydration would give diethyl ether instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂SO₄ does not reduce ethanol to ethane. Diethyl ether forms at 140°C (lower temperature) with excess alcohol, not at 170°C with excess acid. Acetylene requires removal of two molecules of H₂ equivalent, which does not occur here. The temperature of 170°C is the key clue for ethene formation.

questions.question_text: Amit drops a grey calcium compound into water in his chemistry lab and notices vigorous gas evolution. He collects the gas and burns it, observing a luminous smoky flame. When he passes the same gas through ammoniacal silver nitrate solution, a white precipitate forms. The gas Amit produced is:

options.text: Methane, produced from aluminium carbide and water
Ethene, produced from calcium oxide and water
Acetylene, produced from calcium carbide and water
Hydrogen, produced from calcium and water

questions.explanation_correct: The grey calcium compound is calcium carbide (CaC₂). Reaction with water produces acetylene (ethyne): CaC₂ + 2H₂O → C₂H₂ + Ca(OH)₂. Acetylene burns with a luminous smoky flame (high C:H ratio). The white precipitate with ammoniacal AgNO₃ is silver acetylide (Ag₂C₂), confirming a terminal alkyne. All three observations — gas from CaC₂ + H₂O, smoky flame, and silver acetylide formation — are consistent only with acetylene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methane from Al₄C₃ does not give a white precipitate with ammoniacal AgNO₃. Calcium oxide reacts with water to give Ca(OH)₂, not a gas. Calcium does produce H₂ with water, but H₂ burns with a pale blue flame and does not form silver acetylide. Only acetylene fits all the observations.

questions.question_text: Priya is preparing nitrobenzene in her organic chemistry practical. She takes benzene in a round-bottom flask, adds a mixture of concentrated HNO₃ and concentrated H₂SO₄, and heats the mixture at 50-55°C with constant stirring. After the reaction, she pours the mixture into cold water and observes an oily yellow layer settling at the bottom. The role of concentrated H₂SO₄ in this reaction is to:

options.text: Act as a reducing agent that converts HNO₃ to NO₂⁺
Act as a protonating agent that generates the nitronium ion (NO₂⁺) from HNO₃
Dissolve benzene in the aqueous layer to increase contact
Prevent the reaction from becoming too exothermic by absorbing heat

questions.explanation_correct: Concentrated H₂SO₄ acts as a protonating agent (Bronsted acid) that protonates HNO₃, leading to the generation of the active electrophile, the nitronium ion: HNO₃ + H₂SO₄ → NO₂⁺ + HSO₄⁻ + H₂O. Without H₂SO₄, HNO₃ alone cannot generate sufficient NO₂⁺ to nitrate benzene efficiently. The oily yellow product settling at the bottom is nitrobenzene (denser than water, b.p. 211°C).
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂SO₄ is not a reducing agent — it is a strong acid that protonates HNO₃. It does not dissolve benzene in water (benzene is immiscible). It does not act as a heat sink. Its specific role is generating the electrophile NO₂⁺ by protonation of HNO₃.

questions.question_text: Rohan is given two unlabelled bottles, one containing toluene and the other containing nitrobenzene. His teacher asks him to identify them using a Friedel-Crafts alkylation test with CH₃Cl/anhydrous AlCl₃. Rohan finds that one liquid readily reacts and gives a mixture of xylenes, while the other does not react even after prolonged heating. The bottle that did NOT react contains:

options.text: Toluene, because the methyl group blocks further substitution
Nitrobenzene, because the –NO₂ group deactivates the ring too strongly for Friedel-Crafts reactions
Toluene, because Friedel-Crafts only works on unsubstituted benzene
Nitrobenzene, because –NO₂ is ortho-para directing and blocks the meta position

questions.explanation_correct: Nitrobenzene does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reactions because the –NO₂ group is a powerful ring deactivator. It withdraws electron density so strongly that the ring cannot form the required carbocation-electrophile complex with AlCl₃. Toluene, having an activating –CH₃ group, readily undergoes Friedel-Crafts alkylation to give a mixture of o-xylene and p-xylene (ortho-para direction by –CH₃).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The methyl group in toluene does not block substitution — it activates the ring. Friedel-Crafts reactions work on substituted benzenes as long as the ring is not strongly deactivated. –NO₂ is a meta director, not ortho-para. The reason nitrobenzene fails is the extreme ring deactivation by –NO₂.

questions.question_text: Meera observes the Newman projections of ethane in her textbook and notices that one conformation has all C–H bonds on adjacent carbons as far apart as possible (dihedral angle 60°), while another has them directly aligned (dihedral angle 0°). Her teacher asks which conformation ethane predominantly exists in at room temperature. The correct answer is:

options.text: The eclipsed conformation, because aligned bonds allow maximum orbital overlap
The staggered conformation, because it has minimum torsional strain and is ~12.5 kJ/mol lower in energy
Both conformations are equally populated because rotation about C–C is completely free
Neither — ethane is rigid and cannot rotate about the C–C bond

questions.explanation_correct: The staggered conformation (dihedral angle 60°) is more stable by about 12.5 kJ/mol compared to the eclipsed conformation (dihedral angle 0°). In the staggered form, the C–H bonds on adjacent carbons are maximally separated, minimising torsional strain (electron-electron repulsion between bonding pairs). At room temperature, ethane molecules have enough energy to rotate, but they spend more time near the staggered conformation (energy minimum).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eclipsed conformation has maximum torsional strain, not better orbital overlap. The two conformations are not equally populated — the energy barrier is small but significant enough to favour the staggered form. Ethane does rotate about the C–C bond (it is not rigid), but rotation is not completely free — there is a 12.5 kJ/mol barrier.

questions.question_text: Most deactivating groups on benzene are meta directors. Which of the following is an EXCEPTION — a group that deactivates the ring but still directs electrophiles to ortho and para positions?
questions.explanation_correct: Halogens (–Cl, –Br, –I) are the classic exception. Chlorine deactivates the benzene ring due to its strong −I (inductive electron-withdrawing) effect, which reduces the overall electron density. However, it directs to ortho and para positions because its +M (mesomeric electron-donating) effect — donation of lone pair electrons into the ring — stabilises the ortho/para arenium ion intermediates more effectively than the meta intermediate. The directing effect (+M) and the rate effect (−I) operate through different mechanisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: –NO₂, –COOH, and –CN are all deactivating AND meta directing — they follow the general pattern where deactivating groups direct to meta. Only halogens break this pattern: they are deactivating (−I effect) yet ortho-para directing (+M effect). This makes halogens uniquely exceptional among substituent types.

questions.question_text: The peroxide effect (anti-Markovnikov addition) operates with HBr addition to alkenes. Which of the following hydrogen halides is an EXCEPTION where the peroxide effect does NOT work, despite being structurally similar?

options.text: None — all hydrogen halides show the peroxide effect

questions.explanation_correct: The peroxide effect is exclusive to HBr. With HCl, the H–Cl bond is too strong for the propagation step (Cl· + alkene) to be exothermic, so the radical chain does not sustain. With HI, the H–I bond is too weak, and I· radicals are insufficiently reactive to add to the double bond efficiently; instead, termination dominates. Only HBr has the right thermodynamic balance: both propagation steps are exothermic, sustaining the radical chain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HBr does show the peroxide effect — it is the one halogen acid that works. It is not true that all hydrogen halides show the effect. Both HCl and HI fail to sustain the free radical chain mechanism for different thermodynamic reasons (H–Cl too strong, H–I too weak).

questions.question_text: Cyclic, planar, fully conjugated systems with 4n pi electrons are typically anti-aromatic and highly unstable. Cyclooctatetraene (COT) has 8 pi electrons but is an EXCEPTION because it is:

options.text: Aromatic with 8 pi electrons, satisfying a modified Huckel rule
Non-aromatic because it adopts a non-planar tub-shaped conformation to avoid anti-aromaticity
Anti-aromatic but stabilised by hyperconjugation from adjacent C–H bonds
Aromatic because it has alternating single and double bonds in a ring

questions.explanation_correct: Cyclooctatetraene (C₈H₈) has 8 pi electrons (4n, n = 2), which would make it anti-aromatic if it were planar. However, COT avoids the destabilisation of anti-aromaticity by adopting a non-planar, tub-shaped conformation. In this conformation, the p-orbitals do not fully overlap, breaking the continuous conjugation required for anti-aromaticity. As a result, COT behaves as a non-aromatic polyene, undergoing addition reactions like a typical alkene.
questions.explanation_incorrect: COT is not aromatic — 8 pi electrons do not satisfy Huckel's rule (4n + 2). It is not anti-aromatic in practice because it escapes planarity. Hyperconjugation does not stabilise anti-aromatic systems. Simply having alternating bonds does not confer aromaticity; planarity and (4n + 2) pi electrons are also required.

questions.question_text: Why are terminal alkynes (pKa ~25) classified as more acidic than alkenes (pKa ~44) and alkanes (pKa ~50)?

options.text: Because the C≡C triple bond is shorter, making the molecule more compact and polar
Because the sp-hybridised carbon has 50% s-character, holding the bonding electrons closer to carbon and stabilising the conjugate base (acetylide anion)
Because terminal alkynes have fewer hydrogen atoms, so each hydrogen is held more loosely
Because the pi electrons of the triple bond directly weaken the C–H bond through resonance

questions.explanation_correct: The acidity of terminal alkynes is due to the hybridisation of the carbon bearing the acidic H. In an sp-hybridised carbon, the s-character is 50% (compared to 33% in sp² and 25% in sp³). Greater s-character means the bonding electrons are held in an orbital closer to the nucleus, making the C–H bond more polar and the proton easier to remove. The resulting acetylide anion (RC≡C⁻) is stabilised because the lone pair occupies an sp orbital close to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bond length and molecular compactness do not directly explain acidity. The number of hydrogen atoms is irrelevant to individual bond acidity. Pi electrons do not weaken the C–H bond through resonance in alkynes. The determining factor is the percentage s-character of the hybrid orbital forming the C–H bond.

questions.question_text: Why does benzene undergo electrophilic substitution reactions rather than electrophilic addition reactions, unlike typical alkenes?

options.text: Because benzene has no pi electrons available for electrophilic attack
Because addition would destroy the aromatic stabilisation (resonance energy ~150 kJ/mol), whereas substitution preserves it
Because the C–H bonds in benzene are too strong to break by any mechanism
Because benzene is non-polar and cannot interact with electrophiles

questions.explanation_correct: Benzene has a resonance stabilisation energy of about 150 kJ/mol due to its delocalised (4n + 2) pi electron system. Electrophilic addition would permanently disrupt this aromatic sextet by consuming two pi electrons to form new sigma bonds, converting the aromatic ring into a non-aromatic cyclohexadiene. Electrophilic substitution, on the other hand, temporarily disrupts aromaticity in the arenium ion intermediate but restores it when a proton is lost in the final step. The thermodynamic drive to retain ~150 kJ/mol of stabilisation strongly favours substitution over addition.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzene does have pi electrons — it has 6 delocalised pi electrons that are actually attacked by electrophiles. C–H bonds in benzene are broken during substitution, so they are not too strong. Benzene is non-polar overall but its pi cloud is electron-rich and does interact with electrophiles. The key reason is preservation of aromatic stabilisation energy.

questions.question_text: Why is the –OCH₃ group classified as an ortho-para director rather than a meta director in electrophilic aromatic substitution?

options.text: Because –OCH₃ is bulky and sterically blocks the meta position
Because the lone pair on oxygen is donated into the ring by resonance (+M effect), increasing electron density selectively at ortho and para positions
Because –OCH₃ withdraws electrons by induction, destabilising the meta arenium ion
Because the methyl group in –OCH₃ provides hyperconjugation to the meta carbon only

questions.explanation_correct: The –OCH₃ group has a strong +M (mesomeric/resonance) effect: a lone pair on the oxygen atom is conjugated into the benzene ring. When resonance structures are drawn, the additional electron density appears specifically at the ortho and para positions (not meta). This makes the ortho and para arenium ion intermediates more stable, so electrophilic attack is favoured at these positions. The +M effect overrides the weak −I (inductive) effect of oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Steric effects do not explain directing in this case — meta positions are not sterically blocked by –OCH₃. The –OCH₃ group donates electrons by resonance, it does not primarily withdraw by induction. The methyl group in –OCH₃ does not provide hyperconjugation to specific ring positions. The directing effect is due to resonance donation of the oxygen lone pair.
